title: What Do Adinkra Symbols Mean? An In-Depth Look

steps.title: Adinkrahene
steps.content: Adinkrahene The adinkrahene symbolizes leadership and charisma. It’s also called the “king” symbol or “chief of the Adinkra” symbols. Adinkrahene is associated with royalty and greatness and often appears in pottery, fabrics, and architecture. The adinkrahene symbol is the first Ghanaian symbol, from which all others are said to have sprung. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Gye Nyame
steps.content: Gye Nyame Gye nyame means “Except for God.” It’s an Adinkra symbol that represents the omnipotence of God. Gye nyame is inspired by the Akan proverb, “This great panorama of creation dates back to time immemorial, no one lives who saw its beginning and no one will live to see its end, except God.” [2] X Research source

steps.title: Sankofa Bird
steps.content: Sankofa Bird The sankofa bird learns from its past to look to the future. It also stands for learning from past mistakes so you make the right decisions going forward. The sankofa bird symbol serves as a reminder that mistakes are never too big to be undone. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Sankofa Heart
steps.content: Sankofa Heart The heart variation of the sankofa symbol also stands for reaching back to the past. Like the sankofa bird symbol, this version means “Go back and get it!” in the Twi language of the Ghanaian-Akan people. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Dwennimmen
steps.content: Dwennimmen Dwennimmen signifies strength in mind, body, and soul. It translates to the “horns of a ram,” and also symbolizes wisdom, learning, and humility. It reflects the idea that a ram fights before giving in to being killed, which mirrors the connection between strength and humility. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Funtumfunefu Denkyemfunefu
steps.content: Funtumfunefu Denkyemfunefu Funtumfunefu denkyemfunefu is a symbol of unity and diversity. It appears as a 2-headed crocodile with one stomach to represent a group that shares a common destiny. The funtumfunefu denkyemfunefu stands for humanity’s shared connection among its many cultural differences. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Nkyinkyim
steps.content: Nkyinkyim Nkyinkyim is associated with the ups and downs of life. The Akan Twi word nkyinkyim means “twisting.” Nkyinkyim also signifies initiative, dynamism, and versatility, as well as prudence, balance, and vigilance. It’s also linked to an Akan proverb meaning “Life is what you make of it.” [7] X Research source

steps.title: Denkyem
steps.content: Denkyem Denkyem symbolizes adaptability and cleverness. This crocodile symbol is based on the proverb, “The crocodile lives in the water, yet breathes the air.” The denkyem symbol is a reminder to be flexible in life, so you can make your way in and out of any situation that arises. [8] X Research source

steps.title: New Onnim
steps.content: New Onnim Nea onnim represents knowledge and learning. Nea onnim means “he who does not know,” but the full version is "Nea onnim no sua a, ohu," which means “he who does not know can know from learning.” It remains a symbol of lifelong education and the quest for knowledge. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Nsoromma
steps.content: Nsoromma Nsoromma is a symbol of guardianship. It is the Akan word meaning “star,” and translates to “child of the heavens.” Nsoromma reinforces faith in a child’s dependency on a parent and in God and is also associated with love, bonding, and faithfulness in marriage. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Osram Ne Nsoromma
steps.content: Osram Ne Nsoromma A variation of nsoromma that looks like a crescent moon turned on its side with a star above it. It connects the star (husband) to the sky (female) as a symbol of marriage.

steps.title: Aban
steps.content: Aban Aban signals strength and authority. It’s associated with royalty whenever it’s pictured as the king’s castle or home. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Abe Dua
steps.content: Abe Dua Abe Dua is a symbol of wealth, self-sufficiency, and resourcefulness. This palm tree symbol represents the many resources that come from a single palm tree, including wood, fruit, and oil.

steps.title: Abode Santann
steps.content: Abode Santann Symbolizes the totality of the universe with an image of the sun’s rays, the moon, and the eye.

steps.title: Abusua Pa
steps.content: Abusua Pa Means “good family,” as a symbol of family unity, along with love and loyalty between family members.

steps.title: Adwo
steps.content: Adwo Represents peace, tranquility, and quietude; means “calmness.”

steps.title: Agyin Dawuru
steps.content: Agyin Dawuru Stands for faith, alertness, and duty to a leader; it’s based on a story about a servant who beat a gong for the king of the Ashanti people. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Akoben
steps.content: Akoben Signals the readiness to be called to action; it appears as a war horn. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Akofena
steps.content: Akofena Symbolizes both state authority and the authority of a ruler. It appears on Ghana’s coat of arms as a sword of war. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Akoko Nan
steps.content: Akoko Nan Stands for discipline and nurturing as a symbol of kindness . It’s taken from a proverb that means “The foot of a hen steps on the child (chick) but it doesn't kill the child (chick)."

steps.title: Akoma Ntoaso
steps.content: Akoma Ntoaso A symbol of togetherness and unity, as it pertains to a charter. It’s a more specific form of “akoma,” meaning “heart.”

steps.title: Akoma
steps.content: Akoma Represents love, goodwill, and fondness, along with patience, endurance, and consistency. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Ananse Ntentan
steps.content: Ananse Ntentan Symbolizes wisdom, craftiness, and creativity. It’s based on the Ghanaian folklore story of Ananse, a trickster spider whose cunning gets him what he wants.

steps.title: Ani Bere A Enso Gya
steps.content: Ani Bere A Enso Gya Signifies patience, self-discipline, and self-control. It’s linked to the idea that no matter how serious you are, your eyes don’t become red.

steps.title: Anyi Me Aye A
steps.content: Anyi Me Aye A A symbol of being ungrateful and without gratitude; it means “if you will not praise me.”

steps.title: Asaawa
steps.content: Asaawa Represents sweetness, pleasure, and hedonism. It refers to sweet berries, along with the proverb, "Sweetness does not stay in the mouth forever."

steps.title: Asase Ye Duru
steps.content: Asase Ye Duru Stands for providence and the divinity of Mother Earth; means “the earth has weight.”

steps.title: Asetena Pa
steps.content: Asetena Pa A symbol of wealth, spending, and the upper class. It’s connected to a proverb meaning, “Good living is forgetfulness.”

steps.title: Aya
steps.content: Aya Signals endurance, independence, and perseverance, as well as resourcefulness; depicted as a fern. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Bese Saka
steps.content: Bese Saka Symbolizes affluence, power, and plenty. It’s also associated with cola nuts, or togetherness and unity. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Bi Nka Bi
steps.content: Bi Nka Bi Another fern symbol that represents independence, endurance, and defiance against difficulties.

steps.title: Boa Me Na Me Mmoa Wo
steps.content: Boa Me Na Me Mmoa Wo An emblem of cooperation and interdependence. It’s linked to the proverb, “Help me and let me help you” and “The left hand washes the right hand…”

steps.title: Boafo Ye Na
steps.content: Boafo Ye Na Symbolizes support, cooperation, and teamwork; illustrates how rare a willing helper can be.

steps.title: Dame Dame
steps.content: Dame Dame Means craftiness, intelligence, and strategy, and translates to “checkered.” [18] X Research source

steps.title: Dono Ntoaso
steps.content: Dono Ntoaso Stands for alertness, goodwill, and united action as illustrated in a double-talking drum.

steps.title: Dono
steps.content: Dono A symbol of praise, goodwill, and rhythm in the form of a tension-talking drum. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Duafe
steps.content: Duafe Symbolizes women and their feminine qualities, like patience, love, and care; a wooden comb. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Dwantire
steps.content: Dwantire Represents both innocence and guiltlessness as a ram’s head to describe how the innocent do not fear accusation.

steps.title: Eban
steps.content: Eban Signifies safety, security, and love; means “fence.”

steps.title: Epa
steps.content: Epa An emblem of law and justice appearing as a handcuff symbol.

steps.title: Ese ne Tekrema
steps.content: Ese ne Tekrema Stands for improvement, advancement, and growth. It’s also associated with the need for friendliness and interdependence, in the form of teeth and a tongue. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Esono Anantam
steps.content: Esono Anantam A symbol of protection and leadership, as well as power and security; linked to an elephant’s footprint.

steps.title: Fafanto
steps.content: Fafanto Symbolizes tenderness, gentleness, honesty, and fragility in the form of a butterfly’s wings.

steps.title: Fawohodie
steps.content: Fawohodie A symbol of freedom, independence, and self-determination. It’s linked to the proverb, “Freedom walks with suffering.” [22] X Research source

steps.title: Fihankra
steps.content: Fihankra Represents brotherhood, safety, and completeness; illustrated as an enclosed home or compound.

steps.title: Fofo
steps.content: Fofo Acts as a warning against jealousy and covetousness; a flowering plant.

steps.title: Gyawu Atiko
steps.content: Gyawu Atiko Means valor and bravery as a companion symbol to the Kwatakye Atiko, or the back of a gyawu’s (warrior’s) head.

steps.title: Hwehwemudua
steps.content: Hwehwemudua Symbolizes excellence, perfection, and knowledge. It describes a measuring rod or ruler. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Hye Wo Nhye (Hye Anhye)
steps.content: Hye Wo Nhye (Hye Anhye) Stands for toughness and permanence, along with the idea of being unburnable.

steps.title: Kete Pa
steps.content: Kete Pa A symbol of a good and successful marriage, as represented by a “good bed.”

steps.title: Kokuromotie
steps.content: Kokuromotie Signifies cooperation, participation, and teamwork. It’s also associated with harmony, and a proverb stating, “We don't bypass the thumb to tie a knot.”

steps.title: Krado (Mmara)
steps.content: Krado (Mmara) Represents the authority of the court as a symbol of law and order. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Kramo Bone Amma Yeanhu Kramo Pa
steps.content: Kramo Bone Amma Yeanhu Kramo Pa A symbol which warns against deception and hypocrisy among Muslims; separates the idea of a good and bad Muslim.

steps.title: Krapa (Musuyidee)
steps.content: Krapa (Musuyidee) Symbolizes spiritual balance, good fortune, and good luck. “Krapa” refers to a “good soul,” while a “musuyidee” removes filth or evil.

steps.title: Kuronti ne Akwamu
steps.content: Kuronti ne Akwamu Stands for democracy and the sharing of ideas; the two groups (kuronti and akwamu) can form a village council and signify working together.

steps.title: Kwatakye Atiko
steps.content: Kwatakye Atiko Symbolizes valor and bravery; also known as gyawu atiko, which illustrates the hairstyle of Kwatakye, a famous warrior.

steps.title: Kyemfere
steps.content: Kyemfere Represents knowledge, experience, and service. It’s also associated with rarity and antiquity, as seen by a potsherd, or broken piece of ceramic.

steps.title: Mako
steps.content: Mako A symbol of inequality and uneven development; from a proverb that says, “All peppers on the same plant don't ripen at the same time."

steps.title: Mate Masie
steps.content: Mate Masie Represents wisdom, knowledge, and prudence. It involves the idea of keeping wisdom to use again. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Mekyea Wo
steps.content: Mekyea Wo Signifies greeting, recognition, and respect. When members of the Akan ethnic group meet, they greet each other to recognize the other person’s humanity.

steps.title: Menso Wo Kenten
steps.content: Menso Wo Kenten Stands for economic self-reliance and industry; means “I am not carrying your basket.”

steps.title: Mframadan
steps.content: Mframadan Symbolizes resilience and the ability to face life’s challenges; represented by a well-ventilated house. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Mmeramubere
steps.content: Mmeramubere A female cross to symbolize warmth, sunshine, and vitality.

steps.title: Mmeramutene
steps.content: Mmeramutene A male cross associated with sunlight, warmth, and endurance.

steps.title: Mmere Dane
steps.content: Mmere Dane Signifies the temporary nature of good times and how time changes.

steps.title: Mpatapo
steps.content: Mpatapo A symbol of pacification, reconciliation, and forgiveness, also known as a pacification knot.

steps.title: Mpuannum
steps.content: Mpuannum Represents loyalty and priestly office with the image of 5 tufts of hair. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Nea Ope Se Obedi Hene
steps.content: Nea Ope Se Obedi Hene Stands for leadership qualities and skills; it refers to “he who wants to be king.”

steps.title: Nkonsonkonson
steps.content: Nkonsonkonson An emblem of unity and community that looks like a chain.

steps.title: Nkotimsefo Mpua
steps.content: Nkotimsefo Mpua Represents loyalty and a readiness to serve; illustrated by a hairstyle used by court attendants.

steps.title: Nkrabea
steps.content: Nkrabea A symbol of fate and determinism. It’s also associated with inequality to show that everyone’s destiny is unique.

steps.title: Nkyemu (Nkyimu)
steps.content: Nkyemu (Nkyimu) Signifies precision and quality craftsmanship, which is mirrored by the image of a cross design used in Adinkra cloth.

steps.title: Nnamfo Pa Baanu
steps.content: Nnamfo Pa Baanu Represents friendship and companionship; refers to “two good friends.”

steps.title: Nsaa
steps.content: Nsaa Stands for excellence and authenticity as shown by a well-woven cloth.

steps.title: Nserewa
steps.content: Nserewa A symbol of affluence and wealth in the form of cowries, a pre-colonial form of currency in West Africa. It can also symbolize something sacred when used by priests.

steps.title: Nteasee
steps.content: Nteasee Signifies both understanding and cooperation.

steps.title: Nyame Baatanpa (Awurade Baatanfo)
steps.content: Nyame Baatanpa (Awurade Baatanfo) Describes the caring and nurturing quality of God when seen as a good parent.

steps.title: Nyame Biribi Wo Soro
steps.content: Nyame Biribi Wo Soro Signifies hope and inspiration; taken from a proverb meaning “God, there is something in the heavens; let it come to me.” [28] X Research source

steps.title: Nyame Dua
steps.content: Nyame Dua Symbolizes God’s presence and protection in the form of a tree stump, seen as God’s tree.

steps.title: Nyame Nti
steps.content: Nyame Nti Represents both faith and trust in God; means “by God’s grace” or “because of God.” [29] X Research source

steps.title: Nyame Nwu Na Mawu
steps.content: Nyame Nwu Na Mawu Stands for the soul’s immortality and is illustrated by the words, “God won’t die for me to die.” [30] X Research source

steps.title: Nyansapo
steps.content: Nyansapo A symbol of wisdom, ingenuity, intelligence, and patience; it means “wisdom knot.”

steps.title: Obohemaa
steps.content: Obohemaa Stands for preciousness and treasure. It means “queen of stones,” which refers to a diamond.

steps.title: Odo Nyera Fie Kwan
steps.content: Odo Nyera Fie Kwan A symbol of love taken from a proverb that means, “Love does not lose its way home.” [31] X Research source

steps.title: Ohene Aniwa
steps.content: Ohene Aniwa Symbolizes vigilance, intelligence, protection, and security. It’s also associated with defense, power, and far-sightedness, and refers to the “king’s eyes.”#Okodee Mmowere Signifies strength, bravery, and power; describes the talons of an eagle.

steps.title: Okuafo Pa
steps.content: Okuafo Pa Represents diligence, hard work, and entrepreneurship; illustrated by a good farmer.

steps.title: Osrone
steps.content: Osrone Stands for the moon, along with a proverb that means, “It takes the moon some time to go round the notion.” [32] X Research source

steps.title: Owo Foro Adobe
steps.content: Owo Foro Adobe Signifies ingenuity and excellence, in addition to performing an impressive or unusual feat as shown by a snake climbing up a palm. [33] X Research source

steps.title: Owuo Atwedee
steps.content: Owuo Atwedee Stands for the certainty and universality of death, also called the ladder of death. [34] X Research source

steps.title: Pa Gya
steps.content: Pa Gya A symbol of war represented by the phrase, “to strike (or make) fire.” [35] X Research source

steps.title: Pempamsie
steps.content: Pempamsie Symbolizes foresight, readiness, and valor; also associated with being steadfast, fearless, and hardy. [36] X Research source

steps.title: Sepow
steps.content: Sepow A symbol of justice, which is described as an executioner’s knife.

steps.title: Som Onyankopon
steps.content: Som Onyankopon Signifies the devotion and worship of God.

steps.title: Sunsum (Ntoro)
steps.content: Sunsum (Ntoro) Stands for spiritual purity and the cleanliness of the soul; The Akan people believe that God the creator comes to a child through their father, while a mother transfers mogya, or blood.

steps.title: Tabono
steps.content: Tabono Symbolizes strength, confidence, and persistence as shown by an oar. [37] X Research source

steps.title: Tamfo Bebre
steps.content: Tamfo Bebre Represents ill-will, jealousy, and envy; means “the enemy will suffer.”

steps.title: UAC Nkanea
steps.content: UAC Nkanea Signifies technological advancement as depicted by UAC lights, which are street lights.

steps.title: Wawa Aba
steps.content: Wawa Aba A symbol of being hardy, tough, and persevering, as seen by the seed of the tropical wawa tree. [38] X Research source

steps.title: Wo Nsa Da Mu
steps.content: Wo Nsa Da Mu Stands for democracy and pluralism; inspired by a proverb that means, “When your hands are inside the dish, people don't eat everything and leave you nothing.”

steps.title: Woforo Dua Pa
steps.content: Woforo Dua Pa Represents supporting good causes in the form of “climbing a good tree.” [39] X Research source

steps.title: Adinkra symbols are symbols of concepts, proverbs, and sayings.
steps.content: Adinkra symbols are symbols of concepts, proverbs, and sayings. The themes found in Adinkra symbols come from proverbs, folktales, and expressions of the Akan peoples of Ghana. The intricate list of symbols mentions themes ranging from love, bravery, and faith in God to democracy, protection, and wealth. They take inspiration from mythical characters, everyday objects, and elements of the natural world. Adinkra means “goodbye” or “farewell” in the Twi dialect that is used by the Akan ethnic group; Akans include nearly half the population of Ghana. [40] X Research source

steps.title: Adinkra symbols originated in Gyaman, a former kingdom in Ghana.
steps.content: Adinkra symbols originated in Gyaman, a former kingdom in Ghana. They date back to Nana Kofi Adinkra, the king of Gyaman, who wore patterned cloth as a way to express his sorrow at being captured. Adinkra was solely associated with funerary wear in the 19th century but was eventually worn for different special occasions. [41] X Research source

steps.title: Adinkra symbols appear on cloth, pottery, and logos.
steps.content: Adinkra symbols appear on cloth, pottery, and logos. They’re also used as decor for wood carvings, pottery, and buildings. The symbols are not simply decoration, but are culturally significant because they represent meaning based on Akan philosophy, concepts, and aphorisms. [42] X Research source

steps.title: Adinkra also refers to the type of cloth stamped with Adinkra symbols.
steps.content: Adinkra also refers to the type of cloth stamped with Adinkra symbols. Making Adinkra cloth involves a specific process wherein weavers divide the cloth into squares with lines made from bark dye. They then stamp the Adinkra designs onto the cloth using pieces of calabash gourd dipped in ink. Adinkra designs originally appeared in only black or reddish brown, but now include multiple colors. [43] X Research source

steps.title: What religion do Adinkra symbols fall under?
steps.content: What religion do Adinkra symbols fall under? Adinkra symbols are emblems of the Akan people of Ghana. The Akan mostly reside in southern and central Ghana and the southeastern part of the Ivory Coast. The symbols have traditionally been used within the indigenous Akan religion, while today most Akans are Christian, with a Muslim minority among them. [44] X Research source

steps.title: Who is the god in the Akan religion?
steps.content: Who is the god in the Akan religion? The Akan indigenous religion believes in a supreme being called Onyame. Onyame’s other names reflect their best qualities, including Amosu, Giver of Rain, Amowia, Giver of the Sun, and Amaomee, Giver of Plenitude. Onyame is thought to be female and is associated with the moon. Within this polytheistic religion, Onyame is joined by Onyankopon, who is male and associated with the sun. Odomankoma is the 3rd god in the religion who joins Onyame and Onyankopon into one. [45] X Research source

steps.title: What are Adinkra codes?
steps.content: What are Adinkra codes? Adinkra symbols often act as a graphic representation of certain codes. These codes depict the mathematical relationship between certain objects. The symbols do this by starting with squares, cubes, and other geometric shapes. The structure within the symbol uses patterns that go by certain rules. For instance, white dots and black dots cannot share the same vertical position, so black dots cannot appear to be as high as white dots. The purpose of codes is to help the symbols communicate a complex idea through a simple image. [46] X Research source
